Award.AbstractNarration:
This award facilitates scientific research using the large new computational resource named Blue Waters being developed by IBM and scheduled to be deployed at the University of Illinois. It provides travel funds to support technical coordination between the principal investigators, the Blue Waters project team and vendor technical team.

The current standard model for Type Ia supernovae is the explosion of a carbon-oxygen white dwarf near the Chandrasekhar mass. Despite 50 years of study and a good qualitative understanding of the relevant physics, a quantitative model for these explosions that the community can agree upon is lacking. On Blue Waters, the problem will be solved using three new, highly scalable codes. White dwarf ignition will be followed using the low Mach number code, MAESTRO; turbulent nuclear burning will be simulated using the compressible AMR code, CASTRO; and radiation transport will be followed using the 3D implicit Monte Carlo code, SEDONA. All three codes have been proven to scale on at least tens of thousands of processors.

Major resources, both computational and observational, are being invested by the US and Europe in attempts to discover and understand Type Ia supernovae. Part of the reason is their application to the dark energy problem in cosmology. These supernovae are also a laboratory for studying combustion in a situation where long time scales and large length scales allow phenomena to develop that are not terrestrially observable. Each of the three codes being developed to study supernovae has potential application outside of astrophysics, e.g., in combustion science and inertial fusion. The project will also help to train the next generation of computational physicists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had three goals: 1) to use large scale simulation on oneof the world's fastest computers (Blue Waters) to achieve a betterunderstanding of how Type Ia supernovae explode; 2) to further developcodes and visualization techniques that made effective use of the BlueWaters machine; and 3) to train a new generation of computationalphysicists capable of using such powerful hardware for diverseproblems. The major benefit of the award was not so much the money,but the early access to, and large amount of time spent on the machine.


Type Ia supernovae are some of the biggest thermonuclear explosions inthe universe. A solar mass or so of carbon and oxygen is incinerated,in less than a second, to iron. The white dwarf star that explodes iscompletely disrupted. This kind of supernova has been used as a``standard candle'' by the cosmologists to show the existence of darkmatter, and is also responsible for making most of the iron in theuniverse, but just how the white dwarf blows up has long beenmysterious. The calculations we carried out used codes that scale wellon 100,000 processors or more and allowed us to peer into the deepinterior of the white dwarf and follow, with the necessary fineresolution, the ignition of the runaway, and its propagation as a``turbulent combustion front'' to the surface of the star. Thiscombustion was similar to (and just as complicated as) what occurs ina car engine, but nuclear burning rather than chemical. We showed forthe first time that the explosion was inherently ``lopsided'', thatthe supernova would blow up first on one side and end upasymmetrical. Far less of the star burned in this initial ascendingphase of the explosion than previously thought, and so the starexpanded less. It is believed that after the turbulent combustion phaseis over, a spontaneous nuclear detonation will consume the remainder ofthe star. Because the star is denser when this detonation ignites, itwill burn to higher temperature and make more iron and a brightersupernova.


As part of our studies, we continued the development of two codes,CASTRO and MAESTRO, that are optimized for the study of radiationhydrodynamics and nuclear burning on massively parallelmachines. These codes have many other potential applications both inand outside of astrophysics, and have both been made available to thepublic. The money we got was used to facilitate collaboration with theoperators and visualizers at the Blue Waters computer and to attendspecialized meetings organized by the Blue Waters consortium. Onepostdoc, Chris Malone, who did most of the work, has now been hired asa permanent computational research staff member at Los Alamos NationalLab. Two graduate students at SUNYSB, Adam Jacobs and Max Katz, alsoworked on the problem and are doing theses in computationalastrophysics. Adam has just accepted a postdoc with the Joint Institutefor Nuclear Astrophysics. Our results were also presented innumerous refereed publications and invited talks at meetings onsupernova research. They were featured in the official documents ofthe Blue Waters Consortium.
